A better way to think about it is that the request expresses the =
intent
of the client but the server is responsible for mapping that back in=
to
the state of the resource (the client is not supposed to have a clue as
=
to how the resource is implemented, and usually doesn't even know what
defi=
nes it as a resource).  Most of the time it just ends up being the
same as =
a flat file store, but the flexibility is there when you need it
because it=
 allows the server to evolve independent of the clients.

We don't need to =
require that the server do something sensible, since
whatever it does shoul=
d be in the best interests of the resource.

This is also why the Web does =
not support write-back caching.

....Roy
